comment._content:
In 1954 this would have stood  for 99 years of  progress for the NSWGR ... a C38 class locomotive (3801) and the air-conditioned Newcastle Flyer below the clocktower of Sydney's Central Station. Additional air-conditioned trains took passengers to every major city in New South Wales usually hauled behind a mighty 38-class loco.

Fifty years later the steam locomotive is a thing of the past, so is the Newcastle Flyer (in fact "they" are thinking of removing the tracks into central Newcastle). 

At least in 2011 the clocktower remains and is being refurbished.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
The last steam hauled Newcastle Express (the Newcastle Flyer) ran in late 1970. 

Newcastle City Council wants to terminate the trains at Wickham and remove the tracks into central Newcastle (and thus rejuvenate it!) it's quite an election issue in the Hunter at the moment. Strange though, rejuvenation usually needs people and trains carry people. 

Mind you the trackbed would make wonderful real estate - but forgive my cynicism!

comment._content: And of cause the mighty 3801 itself still remains.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/81028427@N04] An good solution by the NSW Government. Lease the Port of Newcastle and apply the proceeds to the rejuvenation of the city. This includes replacing the current heavy rail with light rail. One would think that this would be a reasonable trade-off (but I don't know current passenger numbers).  The Hunter Street Line (am I the first to use the term?) could be a great start to a new Newcastle light rail system, augmenting buses on longer routes. It will be interesting to see how this one develops. 

But please, powers that be, retain and preserve Newcastle Railway Station. The railway has served Newcastle well since 1855.
